I am reserving judgement on the barn til I see how the assets look this time around. If done well, I think it could indeed work as a light backstory.

I do hope unmanned vehicles will come first in this new tech tree.

This.

RE: the barn, I don't like it because I feel it merely serves to reinforce the meme that Kerbals are bumbling idiots destined for player-induced death rather than overly-enthusiastic, not-so-safety-minded but quite brilliant engineers who construct beautiful things. Opinions obviously vary.

Perhaps because I am not so benighted as to think that farmers=morons, I never saw the problem with it.

Look, as noted, modern rocketry got its start on a farm. If you want to launch rockets, you need a lot of open space, and farms generally have that, plus they generally have several outbuildings that make good workshops, especially since most farms have at least one building dedicated to storing and repairing machinery. I suppose if you want to imagine that they have the weight of the Kerbal nation(s?)/race/whatever behind them from the start it seems a little absurd, but then so would be the idea that they start with a very limited budget.

A farm is simply a good setting if you want to depict the agency starting out on a shoestring budget.

I do hope unmanned vehicles will come first in this new tech tree.

Fingers crossed.

Yeah, I don't care, we're not launching the initial liquid fueled rockets of the twentieth century, we're launching Kerbals into space from the beginning. Even the sounding rockets of the '50's would have used better facilities. BARIS starts you out with proper facilities even. The barn is a gimmick of KSP and it is especially jarring to go from the beautifully rendered facilities we had before this explodable buildings nonsense to a poorly rendered barn with farm animals.

Hm, what if we join the Kerbal's story just at the point they start to fly manned missions, if the whole unmanned thing is already over?

Although starting out unmanned would prevent the player from spawning Kerbals at KSC to collect daisys and pebbles to unlock the first tech node(s) ... Afterwards the KSC exploration does not add -that- much, even after all the science gizmos get fielded.

The rockets developed by us were all based on military technology. Don't see why that should be the same with Kerbals.

Related to 'The Barn', I've been reading a book on game design, and in it there is a section about harmony in games, and that good games have a harmony in which everything fits coherently into a smooth user experience. KSP doesn't have (aesthetic) harmony to me, it has more of a compilation of various features, with each feature designed individually rather than being designed to fit together in an aesthetic sense. So when players play and see aesthetically unrelated content, such as the broad difference between the first/second tier buildings compared to the last tier, or porkjet's SP parts compared to the rest of the stock parts, it creates the appearance that the game is unfinished. This may be an issue with the long early access period, because when you have players constantly suggesting new and good ideas, or modders producing new content, it's hard to stick to the original design idea.

I think the best sort of tech tree to satisfy the largest number of players (and hence the most likely) is one that will start in such a way that from the very start of career mode you can build any of the main categories of ship: manned rockets (much like they are at present in early career), rather rudimentary probes, very basic aeroplanes (and possibly mini-rovers)
